column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0019] The nanofibers 30 and the roped fiber bundles 20 of the nanofiber nonwoven 10 may be made in any manner able to produce thermoplastic nanofibers.
#Text=One method to produce suitable nanofibers is melt-film fibrillation.
#Text=Melt-film fibrillation is a high throughput process that extrudes a film or film tube which is fibrillated into small fibers via a high velocity gas.
#Text=Near the exit of the slot or nozzle, high velocity gas shears the film against the tube or slot wall and fibrillates the polymer.

#Text=By tuning the polymer flow, gas velocities, and nozzle geometry, the process can be used to create uniform fibers with diameters down to less than 500 nanometers in diameter, or even less than about 300 nm.
#Text=The amount of nanofibers 30 forming within roped fiber bundles 20 is related to the distance between the die and the take-up mechanism.
#Text=If the take up mechanism (i.e. a belt) is very close to the die, fewer nanofibers 30 would be formed into roped fiber bundles 20.

#Text=When the take-up is further from the die (the distance for example being at least one half of the die width, or at least the die width) a greater percentage of the nanofibers 30 are formed into roped fiber bundles 20.
#Text=[0020] Two technologies using fibrillation have been developed which both utilize a round coaxial nozzle concept.
#Text=The first is nanofibers by gas jet disclosed in several patents (U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=No. 6,520,425, and U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=No. 6,695,992 all of which are incorporated by reference).
#Text=The first technology uses a coaxial design, which also can include multiple coaxial tubes to add a surrounding "lip-cleaning" air, as well as multiple film tubes and multiple air streams.
#Text=[0021] The second technology utilizes an array of nozzles using a melt-film fibrillation process, disclosed in several patents (U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=No. 6,183,670 and U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=No. 6,315,806 all of which are incorporated by reference).
#Text=This technology uses round coaxial nozzles with a central air stream and an outer film tube.

#Text=Molten polymer is fed into an array of these round nozzles with polymer melt and causing some nozzles to produce fine fiber (below 1 micron in diameter) and some to produce larger fiber (greater than 1 micron in diameter).
#Text=Images of roped fiber bundles containing nanofibers produced by this process are shown in FIGS. 2 and 3.
#Text=In this technology, a lower volume of air (higher velocity) is used to fiberize a given weight of resin in this process as compared to meltblowing.

#Text=Additionally, the nature and degree of roping in a nonwoven web containing nanofibers formed from a die comprising an array of holes can be different than nanofibers formed from a continuous slot die.
#Text=FIG. 6 is an SEM image of one embodiment of the nanofiber nonwoven at 300.times..
#Text=[0022] Additionally, there is a variation on the technologies that use a film or slot form (U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=Conceptually, the process is an opened or "infinite" version of the film tube.
#Text=The molten polymer is fed through one or more slots and has fibrillating gas streams and "lip-cleaning" streams essentially parallel to the film slot.
#Text=A film sheet can then be extruded through a slot with a gas stream shearing the film against the lip and fibrillating the sheet into fine fibers.
#Text=[0023] Several other processes exist for making thermoplastic fibers with diameters below 1 micron.

#Text=These processes include several of interest for this invention, including "electro-spinning", "electro-blowing", "melt-blowing", "melt-film fibrillation", "nanofiber by gas jet", "melt fiber bursting", "spinning melt" and "bicomponent" fibers (e.g. islands-in-sea, segmented pie).

#Text=While these processes all produce fibers with submicron diameters, various fiber parameters may be unique to a particular process, such as processable materials, maximum throughput, average diameter and distribution, and fiber length.
#Text=The nanofibers produced may be further processed into yarns, ropes, tapes, knits, woven or nonwoven textile constructions.
